title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots chose not to make any trade moves by the 2025 NFL deadline.
The team traded Keion White and Kyle Dugger before the deadline, decreasing roster depth.
Key areas needing reinforcement include running back, pass-rush, and defensive secondary depth.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses provide free meals and discounts as SNAP benefits are cut during the federal shutdown.
Participating businesses include American Flatbread, Blacker's Bakeshop, and Suya Joint offering free meals with SNAP cards.
Community initiatives like Allandale Farm's free produce market and Ebo Grocery's donation drive support residents impacted by SNAP cuts.

title: Karen Read shuffles defense attorney lineup in wrongful death suit
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Karen Read's legal team shifts as Melick & Porter attorneys withdraw from the wrongful death suit.
New defense attorneys from Tang & Maravelis join Read's team, notably Michael William Bell and Thomas M. Tang.
Read plans legal action against witnesses and state police, citing conspiracy and civil rights violations.

title: FuGaKyu in Brookline closes after 27 years in business
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: FuGaKyu, a Japanese restaurant in Brookline, announced its closure on Facebook after 27 years in business.
The restaurant, known for sushi and shoji decor, will cease operations due to the owner's personal reasons on Nov. 5, 2025.
FuGaKyu previously had locations in Lynnfield and Sudbury, which have also closed; its Coolidge Corner spot opened in 1998.

title: Halsey hospitalized with ‘minor medical emergency’ in between Boston shows
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Halsey hospitalized for a 'minor medical emergency' between two Boston shows, received care at Mass General.
The singer thanked medical staff including Dr. Kian and Dr. Victoria for their assistance during her hospital visit.
Halsey, who has a history of health issues, assured fans she is 'A-Okay' and performed her second show at MGM Music Hall.

title: 18-year-old killed in Belmont moped crash
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An 18-year-old from Watertown died in a moped crash in Belmont after failing to stop for police.
The collision happened at Stults Road and Fairview Avenue with a Honda CRV, resulting in minor injuries to the SUV driver.
The incident is under investigation by Belmont police, Massachusetts State Police, and the Middlesex County DA's office.

title: Feds: Nurse replaced liquid oxy with household cleaner
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Nurse Lori Robertson of Salem, NH, charged with tampering by replacing oxycodone with cleaner for a patient.
Incident occurred at a long-term care facility in Amesbury in March; unclear if cleaner was administered to patient.
Robertson, released on probation, set for a court hearing on November 24; conditions include substance abuse program.

title: AG Campbell skeptical of proposed law to ban ICE agents from wearing masks
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: AG Andrea Campbell expressed skepticism about Massachusetts legislation to ban ICE agents from wearing masks.
Campbell emphasized that state laws can't effectively enforce mask bans on federal agents like ICE.
State Rep. Jim Hawkins filed a bill to prohibit mask-wearing by law enforcement, facing support and challenges.

title: Birds of Paradise, Brightonâ€™s travel-themed cocktail bar, closes at the Speedway
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Birds of Paradise, a travel-themed cocktail bar in Brighton, closed permanently on October 31.
The bar, opened by Ran Duan in 2022, was known for globally-inspired cocktails themed after various destinations.
Ran Duan's involvement in an ongoing investigation was reported, with bar oversight transferred to colleagues before closure.

title: Child struck by school bus, driver arrested in Medway
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A child on a bike was struck by a school bus near Francis J. Burke Elementary in Medway, no serious injuries reported.
Bus driver Kenneth Benjamin, 69, was arrested for disorderly conduct after the crash, not the collision itself.
Benjamin was charged for disorderly conduct and cited for failing to stop at a crosswalk, arraigned in Wrentham District Court.
